snippet: The use of long-acting, reversible birth control like intrauterine devices and implants has risen sharply among teenagers in the last decade, new federal data show.
abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention data shows sharp increase in use of long-term birth control among teenagers; 7 percent of eight million young women visiting contraceptive clinics funded by Title X program used long-term methods in 2013, up from .04 percent in 2005.
lead_paragraph: The use of long-acting, reversible birth control like intrauterine devices and implants has risen sharply among teenagers in the last decade, new federal data show.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
